quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've always been really curious about the product culture at Miro, partly because everyone I've ever met from Miro has been super interesting and super smart, and partly because they've been able to grow as a business and a product in an incredibly competitive market.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-relevant lens: product culture as a driver of differentiation and growth even in crowded markets.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get really deep into the product values and principles at Miro, their product development process, how Varun approaches competitive threats, how a bimonthly company-wide product demo ritual led to saving months of engineering work on a feature, plus insights into how Miro got started, how they grow today, and what their product team has learned about working with a large sales org.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Contains a concrete example (a bimonthly demo ritual saving months of engineering work) and signals key actionable areas like principles, process, and handling competition.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The first one is practicing empathy to gain insights. It's not just practicing empathy in terms of customers and figuring out what customer pain points and problems we can solve, but given our distributed nature in terms of having a global footprint and a lot of our go to market teams, folks in sales and marketing and customer success are in different continents or geographies, we have to make sure that we actually practice that internally.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A practical reframing of empathy as an internal operating practice (not just a customer research skill) for distributed orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When we are interacting with folks, let's say in San Francisco, and those folks are out there meeting some of our large customers and stuff, how do we, in the product organization, understand their perspective, and bring that perspective into how we design, prioritize and build products?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete mechanism: systematically importing GTM/customer-facing perspective into product design and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: practicing teamwork, how do we actually come together as a team, and bring down the silos that might exist across functions?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A simple, memorable articulation of the goal behind cross-functional product culture: actively dismantling silos.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most powerful things that I've seen work is the questions that you ask, the questions that you ask when you're going through product review or you are going to sit down and talk to someone and trying to understand why did they prioritize something over the other
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Offers an actionable lever for better collaboration: use product reviews to interrogate decision rationale via questions, not directives.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think just trying to double click and getting to the details in terms of what insight led them to recommend certain things or make a left turn or a right turn is where I think is the most powerful way to make sure that those things are informed through practicing empathy internally and externally.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: “double click” on the underlying insights behind decisions to ensure empathy-driven alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
quotes.text: The one thing that's really interesting, Lenny, around the way Miro is set up is that our product organization is actually based in Europe and our go-to-market organization is worldwide.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights an operating model (centralized product, globally distributed GTM) that creates specific collaboration demands and advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
quotes.text: What that sort of leads to is a couple of practices that we have as part of our culture. The first one is practicing empathy to gain insights.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete cultural practice—empathy—as an explicit mechanism for better product decisions in a distributed org.

quotes.topic_title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
quotes.text: It's not just practicing empathy in terms of customers and figuring out what customer pain points and problems we can solve, but given our distributed nature in terms of having a global footprint and a lot of our go to market teams, folks in sales and marketing and customer success are in different continents or geographies, we have to make sure that we actually practice that internally.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: empathy isn’t only customer-facing; it must be applied internally across time zones and functions.

quotes.topic_title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
quotes.text: When we are interacting with folks, let's say in San Francisco, and those folks are out there meeting some of our large customers and stuff, how do we, in the product organization, understand their perspective, and bring that perspective into how we design, prioritize and build products?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on turning GTM/customer-facing learnings into product design and prioritization inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
quotes.text: I'll talk a little bit around how we are structured in the product organization so that it's a cross-functional perspective we bring to everything that we're doing because we believe the best work happens when we bring different diverse perspectives to the problem and then co-create the outcome that the customer is looking for.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Encapsulates a cross-functional collaboration philosophy: diverse perspectives + co-creation produce better customer outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
quotes.text: One of the most powerful things that I've seen work is the questions that you ask, the questions that you ask when you're going through product review or you are going to sit down and talk to someone and trying to understand why did they prioritize something over the other and was it something that was done through interactions they've had with folks internally or externally?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A practical empathy-building tactic: use reviews/1:1s to interrogate prioritization decisions through the lens of stakeholder and customer interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
quotes.text: I think just trying to double click and getting to the details in terms of what insight led them to recommend certain things or make a left turn or a right turn is where I think is the most powerful way to make sure that those things are informed through practicing empathy internally and externally.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A repeatable review question (“what insight led you here?”) as a lightweight framework to ground decisions in evidence and empathy.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
quotes.text: Maybe there are certain things, for example, anytime we're trying to build a new experience, one of the approach we want to take is very quickly validate that our original hypothesis, is that sound or not.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Advice to reduce risk on new experiences by explicitly validating the initial hypothesis early.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
quotes.text: We are big fans of the Design Sprint framework, what Jake Knapp has done I think is really amazing. In a short five-day window, you can get a small set of people to quickly mock up a concept, convert it into some sort of a prototype and then go out there and get some sort of a validation.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A concrete methodology (Design Sprint) with a specific cadence (five days) for rapid prototyping and validation.

quotes.topic_title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
quotes.text: Oftentimes when we are working on some of these new things, we have our product teams that are focused on zero to one initiatives, run this five-day initiative, and at the end of it we say, "Oh, this is great. Who did you get insight from?"
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable review prompt that reinforces the habit of tying prototypes back to real user/customer insight sources.

quotes.topic_title: Design Sprints and the Talktrack product decision
quotes.text: In a short five-day window, you can get a small set of people to quickly mock up a concept, convert it into some sort of a prototype and then go out there and get some sort of a validation.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method (5-day Design Sprint) for rapidly validating product hypotheses with prototypes and user feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Design Sprints and the Talktrack product decision
quotes.text: We had two fundamental choices we could make. One, we could go down the path of what everyone's doing where you could do a screen recording and then spit out a series of videos, like pixels being captured. Or what we did was we actually went down a different path and the path that we went down was we basically synchronized the movement of the board.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A clear example of deliberately not following the default industry approach, and instead choosing an interaction model aligned to the product’s core value.

quotes.topic_title: Design Sprints and the Talktrack product decision
quotes.text: What our users want to do is they want to use Miro for collaboration. While communication is an important aspect of how teams come together, where we believe our sweet spot is that we want people to use Miro for collaboration.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A positioning insight that distinguishes “collaboration” from “communication” and guides product decisions toward the core job-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Design Sprints and the Talktrack product decision
quotes.text: We were able to develop this insight by practicing empathy as part of the Design Sprint framework when we went and started to show our original concept and we walled and built on top of that.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights empathy-driven user research inside a sprint as the mechanism for uncovering the key product insight and iterating on the concept.

quotes.topic_title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
quotes.text: The fundamental value that Miro provides is that we enable teams. I think what's unique about our product, and we can talk about the capabilities and roadmaps and use cases that we are investing in and we already have as part of the product, is that we take a team-centric lens.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A clear differentiation framework: compete by optimizing for cross-functional teams rather than a single persona.

quotes.topic_title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
quotes.text: So we're not saying, "Hey, we're building a tool that just works for designers," or "Hey, we're building a tool that just works for engineers." Because we fundamentally believe that innovation happens when cross-functional teams come together.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A product strategy mental model that guides prioritization: build for collaboration across roles because that’s where innovation happens.

quotes.topic_title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
quotes.text: When you look at the problem through that lens, you realize that you have to actually architect your solution. You have to think about the use cases and you have to go and prioritize certain experiences that are different and our customers see value in that, right?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: a team-centric strategy requires deliberate architecture and prioritization, not just feature additions.

quotes.topic_title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
quotes.text: What we find is that Miro is used equally by companies in manufacturing, by companies in healthcare, by companies in architecture and engineering and construction functions, by companies that are in aerospace, governmental agencies and medical agencies and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A concrete example of broad applicability as a moat—expanding beyond “digital design” into many verticals.

quotes.topic_title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
quotes.text: I would say on top of that, we are a big fan of our community and we believe that community love is what drives us. That's the fuel that keeps us going every single day.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable growth/retention lever: community as an ongoing competitive advantage and motivation engine.

quotes.topic_title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
quotes.text: Give or take about 1,800 employees at Miro globally across all of the 12 hubs, and specifically in terms of the number of product managers, there are over 450 PMs in the team.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Concrete scale data that helps practitioners calibrate what “large PM org” looks like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
quotes.text: Yeah, so I would say it's maybe a hybrid structure that we have, but the foundation of the team setup is around persona.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A clear organizing principle: use a hybrid org design, anchored primarily on user personas.

quotes.topic_title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
quotes.text: We have what we refer to as streams, some companies refer to as domains, but essentially it's a set of individuals that are focused on solving the problems for a key persona.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Defines a reusable structural unit (“streams/domains”) and what it’s accountable for: a persona’s problems.

quotes.topic_title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
quotes.text: Then finally there are some just horizontal sort of streams, if you will.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights a practical complement to persona streams: horizontal teams for cross-cutting capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
quotes.text: At the heart of it is we are focused on personas and we are sort of aligning people around solving problems and creating value for that persona.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of the operating model: align teams to create value for a specific persona.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding persona silos with AMPED and reviews
quotes.text: The first one is actually when we think about the product org, we call our org, it's called AMPED, A-M-P-E-D.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete cross-functional org design meant to prevent persona-based teams from creating fragmented product experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding persona silos with AMPED and reviews
quotes.text: AMPED stands for analytics, marketing, product, engineering and design.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Defines the AMPED model explicitly so teams can replicate the exact functional mix.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding persona silos with AMPED and reviews
quotes.text: We have these product reviews that happen. We generally classify anything that we are doing in terms of its complexity around a small, medium or high complexity, and anything that's being worked on is actually being shared with the entire organization.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Describes a scalable review-and-transparency mechanism (complexity tiers + broad sharing) to maintain alignment and holistic thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding persona silos with AMPED and reviews
quotes.text: When I'm thinking about building a new feature, I have a checklist in front of me where I can say, "Here are the 10 things that I need to think of that I need to incorporate early on in my thinking in the architecture, in the definition of the process, so that it doesn't come downstream."
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Gives a practical tactic—an enterprise requirements checklist—to bake cross-cutting constraints into feature development early.

quotes.topic_title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
quotes.text: A big part of that is how are you going to think about positioning, how are you going to think about competitive differentiation? How are you going to package it up so that the sellers that are out there are able to position it in a way that the customer, in this case the buyer, might be an IT professional, might a line business leader, can basically see the full vision of where we are going?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Explains the practical reason to embed product marketing: turning shipped features into clear positioning, differentiation, and sales-ready packaging for specific buyer personas.

quotes.topic_title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
quotes.text: I think by having product marketing as part of AMPED, we now bring that unique perspective that may be missing in certain teams.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights the organizational design insight that product marketing adds a distinct lens that product/engineering/design teams often lack.

quotes.topic_title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
quotes.text: PMs are more acting as product owners or more focused on core problem and solution but not thinking about positioning, because that's so important, especially when you're thinking about a market that we are increasingly in that there is competition there.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Calls out a common gap in product teams—strong problem/solution work without positioning—especially risky in competitive markets.

quotes.topic_title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
quotes.text: One of the core philosophies that I have, Lenny, is that the success of a company is a direct relation of what the competition allows you to do.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for strategy: company outcomes are constrained/enabled by competitive dynamics, not just internal execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
quotes.text: I feel like not many people talk about that, but in many cases in my professional career, and I've been at it for close to 24, 25 years, is that every single instance when I looked at a company accelerated their growth or there was a deceleration of growth, it was a direct relation to what the competition allowed you to do.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Reinforces the competition-as-primary-variable view with an experience-based claim spanning 24–25 years.

quotes.topic_title: Competition as the key variable in growth
quotes.text: I think you can, in general, sort of look at every single category and you can say that there was a category leader and they were growing at a certain clip or a certain pace and all of a sudden there were a bunch of entrants that get in and what happens to your growth rate? It's all dependent on how strong is the competitor in terms of providing a good enough solution? That's one. The second is how strong is the competition in terms of their distribution outreach? Then the third thing is how strong is the competition in terms of the pricing and packaging?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A practical 3-variable framework for diagnosing growth slowdowns through competitor capability, distribution, and pricing/packaging.

quotes.topic_title: Competition as the key variable in growth
quotes.text: It depends on who the competition is and what is their unfair advantage here.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A tactical prompt for strategy: explicitly identify the competitor’s “unfair advantage” before deciding how to respond.

quotes.topic_title: Competition as the key variable in growth
quotes.text: I think it sort of comes down to how do you think about your unique place relative to all of these players, and in your customer's mind are they able to clearly understand what is the unique value that you deliver relative to everything else?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Emphasizes differentiation as a customer-perception problem, not just a feature checklist.

quotes.topic_title: Competition as the key variable in growth
quotes.text: Products either get better over a period of time or they get worse. Products never remain the same.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that forces teams to treat every release as either improving or degrading the user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Products always get better or worse
quotes.text: products either get better over a period of time or they get worse. Products never remain the same.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A simple forcing function that frames product work as continuous progress or regression, never neutral maintenance.

quotes.topic_title: Products always get better or worse
quotes.text: every single day, every single time somebody is pushing your code to production and you're releasing a feature or an enhancement, you are making the product better or you're making the product worse, but the products never remain same.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Turns each release into an explicit quality bet, encouraging teams to evaluate impact before shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Products always get better or worse
quotes.text: So with every release that your competitor is making and every release that you're making, you're either making chess points, moves against them, positive points, or you're going negative.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A competitive “chess move” model for thinking about releases as relative gains/losses in customers’ minds.

quotes.topic_title: Products always get better or worse
quotes.text: I think that framework, if you have in mind, it actually drives an insane amount of clarity in terms of what you're doing and what the impact is going to be.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Highlights how adopting a relative-advantage lens can sharpen prioritization and expected outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Products always get better or worse
quotes.text: That all of these decisions that you are making ladder up to that final sort of play that you have to do in terms of the market consolidation that eventually happens.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Connects day-to-day product bets to the long-term endgame of category standardization and consolidation.

quotes.topic_title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
quotes.text: My personal perspective on this is that what you want to do is that you want to be the first one to hit the brick wall.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for prioritizing speed so you learn (and course-correct) before competitors do.

quotes.topic_title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
quotes.text: This is particularly true when you are in a market that is competitive.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Clarifies when the “hit the brick wall first” philosophy is most applicable: competitive markets.

quotes.topic_title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
quotes.text: speed is the single biggest determinant, in my experience, in terms of who ends up being more successful versus not.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A strong, quotable claim that elevates speed as a primary driver of outcomes for innovation-centric teams.

quotes.topic_title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
quotes.text: but when you are trying to figure out new experiences and stuff and you don't know if it's going to resonate or not, speed is something that you should accelerate for the organization.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: increase iteration speed specifically in high-uncertainty discovery work.

quotes.topic_title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
quotes.text: can you be the first one to hit the brick wall where you have the learning faster than anyone else in the market so that you can decide, "Oh my god, the path that I was going was not the right path. I need to do 10 degrees west or I need to do 30 degrees east."
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Connects speed to a concrete mechanism—faster learning enabling rapid directional changes.

quotes.topic_title: Creating urgency by removing blockers
quotes.text: I think fundamentally the product persona actually wants to move fast. I think the reason why in some cases we are not able to move fast is because of roadblocks that we run into and those roadblocks can manifest themselves into technical challenges, they can manifest them in cells of organizational challenges, they could be priority challenges and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Reframes speed problems as primarily blocker problems (technical/org/prioritization), not motivation problems.

quotes.topic_title: Creating urgency by removing blockers
quotes.text: My fundamental approach to solving that is to ensure that the product leads who are working on these capabilities can instantly raise their hand and call out that there are challenges that they are running into. Then the job of the leadership team, the product management team, is to essentially go and quickly resolve those issues.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A practical operating model: make raising blockers immediate and make leadership accountable for rapid unblocking.

quotes.topic_title: Creating urgency by removing blockers
quotes.text: I think if you are able to resolve those issues, then what it does is it actually starts a virtuous cycle where you can actually start to see those wins. Once you see those wins, you actually create that courage to do more things.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Explains how fast unblocking compounds into momentum and higher ambition over time.

quotes.topic_title: Creating urgency by removing blockers
quotes.text: It's not that they are 10 times faster, it's just that in my observation that they've figured out which part of the core base they should build in versus not, who should be part of their team and who should not be, how they need to define that from a scope perspective, what does success look like, and it's the architecture of bringing all of these things together that actually brings that magic formula line in terms of "Hey, we are able to deliver faster."
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for “fast teams”: speed comes from better build-vs-buy decisions, team composition, scoping, and success definition—not raw output.

quotes.topic_title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
quotes.text: We have a motto in the product org, it's very simple, single sentence, deliver customer value faster with high quality. That's it. Everything that we do, and when I say everything, everything, Lenny, from performance and reward system and measurements, everything is based on this one single statement and it has three attributes.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A crisp operating-system motto that’s explicitly tied to incentives, measurement, and day-to-day execution.

quotes.topic_title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
quotes.text: Anytime as a PM at Miro, when you ship something, we are looking at, "Well, what was the metric you were going to move and how much did it move?"
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Defines “customer value” as measurable usage/metric movement rather than shipping output.

quotes.topic_title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
quotes.text: From the time you came up with the idea to the time that you actually pitched a solution to the time you actually shipped it, to the time we actually moved the metric, it's information that has been collected and is being made available to the organization.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A practical speed methodology: instrument end-to-end cycle time through metric impact, not just delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
quotes.text: On a regular basis, like when we ship stuff on a monthly basis, our design leadership team does a triage of everything that got shipped into high quality or not high quality. It's just like a binary function, and we're doing that and we're saying, "Hey, the reason why we believe it's not high quality is because A, B, C, D, E and we're making it available to other designers so they can actually start to build that telemetry in terms of some things are more subjective."
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A lightweight, repeatable quality system: monthly binary classification plus written rationale to teach judgment at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
quotes.text: Because it's one of those things, it's like if you've never seen colors and I ask you, "Lenny, describe pink and compare that to red," and if you haven't seen colors, how do you describe colors? You can't.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why quality is better taught via examples and calibration than long definitions.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
quotes.text: The core philosophy there is velocity is more like the game of golf where you're just playing against yourself.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for measuring velocity as self-improvement rather than competition across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
quotes.text: What we are interested in is from the time that you have an insight, from the time you believe "I can do something unique for my user, for my persona," how long does it take for you to actually deliver that value?
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Defines a practical, end-to-end cycle-time metric anchored on value delivery from initial insight.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
quotes.text: We have a product process that we follow, which starts with a P-strat, which is a strategy, and then we go into P0, which is definition of the problem, then we go into P1, which is definition of the solution, and then we go into P2, which is once the solution is shipped, are we hitting the metrics that we originally had defined upfront before we decided to work on this.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: A concrete stage-gate framework that ties strategy and problem/solution work to post-ship metric impact.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
quotes.text: You have all of these stage gates and then we basically classify everything that we are doing in small, medium, large.
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Shows a simple sizing system that enables apples-to-apples cycle-time benchmarking across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
quotes.text: "Oh, wait a second, actually it seems like I took way more time in the problem definition stage. Let me actually try to go talk to this other product team that actually did it much faster," or "Oh, I actually did it really, really fast, and the reason why I did it fast was because of this. Let me go share this out with the broader team."
quotes.speaker: Varun Parmar
quotes.context: Illustrates how shared cycle-time data helps teams learn from outliers and spread best practices to improve throughput.
